results.title: Farmyard stories = better move on frog ...
results.creator_credit: Gerben Cath and International Video Books
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dorothy Butler’s Video Books”.
A video designed to encourage children to read and enjoy books. Ten different stories, many from well known books, are told by professional storytellers in a farmyard setting and have been selected for children aged one to five years old. The stories are: “Mrs. Mopple’s washing line”, “Sophie and Jack”, “Better move on frog”, “Teddy at the seaside”, “Bookload of animals”, “Mr. Ginger’s potato”, “Wilberforce goes on a picnic”, “Ambo and the little elephant”, “Peter Pipers at the wildlife park”, “Hairy Mclary from Donaldson’s dairy” Introduced by Dorothy Butler.

results.title: Farms and towns of Slovakia: a Danube River country
results.creator_credit: Ronald Craigen and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Illustrates many aspects of peasant life in Slovakia (Czechoslovakia). Traditional methods of cultivation and harvesting crops are described, but the film shows the changes in methods which are occurring. The village pictured in the film is in the Tatra Mountains, in the northern part of Slovakia.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Ronald Craigen and Louis de Rochemont Associates

results.title: Farming: Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Tom Manefield, Arch Nicholson and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Soviet style”.
Examines the Soviet agricultural system, the collective farms, or Kolkhoz, the State farms, or Sovkhoz and the importance of the agricultural private plot. Credits include: photography by Dean Semler; script by Roger Milliss; edited by Martyn Down; sound by Howard Spry and commentary by Margaret Throsby.

results.title: Farming with nature
results.brief_description: Tells the story of 70 year-old Missouri farmer Gene Poirot and his successful struggle to restore the fertility of a wornout prairie farm. Describes the ecological farming techniques developed by Poirot in the course of fifty years of observation of a natural grasslands ecosystem, drawing on methods from traditional and modern sources.

results.title: Farming with a difference
results.brief_description: The secret of successful farming is scientific management. At a demonstration farm at Hobbs Cross, visiting farmers come to garner the fruits of research. Hobbs Cross is shown to be a practical house of notions that farmers can adapt to their own needs and pockets.

results.title: Farming the forest for woodchip
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Keith Gow
results.brief_description: This film concentrates on the process involved in the production of woodchips in the Eden area of New South Wales, from tree-felling to the shipment of chips to Japan. The film stresses that the logged areas will rejuvenate naturally thus allowing continual use of the forest. For a more critical view of woodchipping see “The Vanishing forest”. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Farming in South China: Si River Valley
results.creator_credit: Louis de Rochemont Associates and Victor Jurgens
results.brief_description: Rich river basin areas make good agricultural lands. In these densely populated areas, thousands of families live by intensive subsistence farming. Land is very scarce. Farm families in the Si River Valley do their own work with crude tools with rice being the dominant crop providing more food value per acre than other grain crops grown in the region. Poverty prevails among most of the population. However there still seems to be happiness among the people as they engage in the coninuous routine of tilling the soil and reaping scant harvests on which they manage to exist.

results.title: Farming for the future
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Bell, Australian National Film Board, Shell Company of Australia, Shan Benson and Geoffrey Collings
results.brief_description: The basic causes of wind and water erosion in Australia, and how in the Mallee areas wind erosion is being checked. Farming for the future means a new approach to old problems, since the farmers themselves suffer most from the effects of impoverished land.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoffrey Bell, Australian National Film Board, Shell Company of Australia, Shan Benson and Geoffrey Collings

results.title: Farming 2000
results.brief_description: Covers a conference held in 1983 by the Australian Rural Adjustment Unit and the National Farmers Federation. The conference examined the major issues facing rural Australia during the 1980’s.

results.title: Farmers of India: the Middle Ganges Valley
results.creator_credit: Louis De Rochemont, United Films, Louis de Rochemont Associates and Victor Jurgens
results.brief_description: Describes aspects of the life of an Indian family near Benares in the fertile Ganges Valley. The film shows methods of farming used in different seasons and emphasises the dependence of most Indians on the soil for their supply of food. Crop failure means starvation. A visit to the city of Benares is shown and the religious rituals observed at the sacred Ganges River are described. The film illustrates aspects of both country and city life in the Ganges Valley.
